roles/ceph/tasks/ceph-fsid.yaml.message:
I need to produce an empty string when no *.conf is found in /etc/ceph.
By doing this I can skip the next two tasks.
The reason of skipping the next two tasks is to cover a new Ceph deployment:

1. It's the first time we deploy the Ceph Cluster => we should skip this validation (it means we should skip the next two tasks)

2. It's a stack update: we should be able to find those parameters and no task should be skipped in this case.

As this is currently written valid DCN deployments will fail this validation.

Please re-write this so that it can handle when multiple external ceph clusters are configured as described here:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/ceph_external.html#configuring-ceph-clients-for-multiple-external-ceph-rbd-services

Basically you could have /etc/ceph/foo.conf, /etc/ceph/bar.conf, /etc/ceph/baz.conf but you only want the one that is not under CephExternalMultiConfig.

The bad point of this decorator function is that if you call it you are executing remote commands on nodes even for test cases that aren't going to be executed (importing a test module is enough for executing this).

tobiko.skip_if supports lazy evaluation so you can put this code in a function called for example openstack_nodes_have_docker() returning a boolean. Then you can create your decorator like below:

 skip_unless_openstack_has_docker = tobiko.skip_unless(openstack_nodes_have_docker)

The decorator can then be used for test cases method or classes assuring openstack_nodes_have_docker method is executed just in time when needed.

hooks/nova_compute_utils.py.message:
you can rewrite this logic as:

```
if config_dev:
    if os.path.exists(config_dev):
        return config_dev
    # LP #1870232:
    raise EphemeralDeviceNotFound("Device {} not found".format(config_dev))
```

Also, before raising the exception, you could log and status_set, then you don't need the custom exception, nor try/except blocks anywhere else
you can just log this in determine_block_device() and not need a try/except block here, let it bubble up

tools/deployment/dev_install_test_site.s.message: I remember we decided not to use bash script libs for airship. When I was working on gate scripts I saw the comment about it on review. Please, don't use libs.

I don't see any definition for AIRSHIP_CONFIG_MANIFEST_DIRECTORY before running this script. It means that the document pull command will download the master version of the code to the temp dir and will use it for deployment. So, this will be a master deployment, not a development one that should be based on the current version of code. So, please, make sure that these scripts will use the current version of the code.
Color code. added a variable for readability

this won't work properly. the set of scripts is constantly changing, and not everybody who will either add new script or rename it or change the order will take into account your solution. hard-coded script names and order is definitely not the best idea, as well as combining pre-install, gate build and gate runner steps into single one. I already worked before on this problem a bit, you can check my patch here https://review.opendev.org/#/c/752132/

in that case it will vary from 8 to 100
I will test out if we need to have a higher minimum than 4. Thanks for the suggestion!

The minimum requirement for the Undercloud is 4 vCPUs (I have verified this as well, you cannot install an Undercloud with anything lower). [1] That leaves the minimum to be 16. I also took an existing Undercloud and compared 4 forks vs 16 forks (1 vCPU vs 4 vCPUs). The deployment time was very similar (+/- two minutes) and still worked even with 1 vCPU. (1) https://images.rdoproject.org/docs/baremetal/requirements.html

swift/common/utils.py.message: so "truthy" isn't a change as much as clarification of existing behavior
wat?  oh... maybe because it doesn't need to be... "started" so it's just the identity function if it's not a generator... ok, maybe.

Yeah -- the main reason we've got this function *at all* is this bit from pep-3333:

> [T]he start_response callable must not actually transmit the response headers. Instead, it must store them for the server or gateway to transmit only after the first iteration of the application return value that yields a non-empty bytestring, or upon the application's first invocation of the write() callable. In other words, response headers must not be sent until there is actual body data available, or until the application's returned iterable is exhausted. (The only possible exception to this rule is if the response headers explicitly include a Content-Length of zero.)
>  
> This delaying of response header transmission is to ensure that buffered and asynchronous applications can replace their originally intended output with error output, up until the last possible moment. For example, the application may need to change the response status from "200 OK" to "500 Internal Error", if an error occurs while the body is being generated within an application buffer.

So, we read until there's some actual body data and the status code that we should send to the client is settled.

Needed this so that

 lti.close is iter(lti).close

playbooks/roles/bifrost-keystone-client-.message: Same could be said for other OS_* variables. Maybe just set it to an empty dict?

It's the ones that don't get overwritten that may cause problems though. We do this in kolla:

for key in $( set | awk '{FS="="}  /^OS_/ {print $1}' ); do unset $key ; done
Other OS_ variables will be overwritten by sourcing openrc.. which makes me think: maybe we should unset OS_CLOUD inside the generated openrc.
